Surface engineering of perovskite catalysts: Using acid treatment to enhance CO and CH4 oxidation activity JeongHyun Cho Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Methodology Investigation Data curation Conceptualization a 1 Jimin Yun Visualization Validation Methodology Investigation Data curation a 1 Minjae Kim Validation Investigation Data curation a Kyung Tae Park Supervision Project administration b Hai Woong Park Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Conceptualization c ⁎ Ji Chul Jung Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering, Myongji University, Yongin 17058, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering, Myongji University Yongin 17058 Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering, Myongji University, Yongin 17058, Republic of Korea b Iron & Steel Process Engineering Research Group, POSCO, Pohang 37859, Republic of Korea Iron & Steel Process Engineering Research Group, POSCO Pohang 37859 Republic of Korea Iron & Steel Process Engineering Research Group, POSCO, Pohang 37859, Republic of Korea c Hydrogen and Low-Carbon R&D Laboratories, POSCO N.EX.T Hub, POSCO Holdings, Pohang 37673, Republic of Korea Hydrogen and Low-Carbon R&D Laboratories, POSCO N.EX.T Hub, POSCO Holdings Pohang 37673 Republic of Korea Hydrogen and Low-Carbon R&D Laboratories, POSCO N.EX.T Hub, POSCO Holdings, Pohang 37673, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally. This study examined the effects of acid treatment on LaMnO3 (LMO) and LaCoO3 (LCO) perovskites and their catalytic performance in CO and CH4 oxidation. Acid treatment selectively removed La cations, creating oxygen vacancies and altering the electronic properties of surface oxygen species and B-site cations. In LCO, it increased the Co2 + concentration while reducing the electron densities of surface oxygen species. These changes reduced T20 by 39 ℃ and 123 ℃ for CO and CH4 oxidation, respectively, after 5 h of acid treatment. However, acid-treated LMO for 5 h exhibited improved CO oxidation (T20 decreased by 49 ℃) owing to enriched surface adsorbed oxygen species but declined CH4 oxidation activity (T20 increased by 77 ℃), attributed to the increased Mn4+ concentration and minimal enhancement in oxygen mobility. This study emphasizes the importance of tailored surface engineering strategies, providing insights into the systematic design of perovskite catalysts for various oxidation reactions. Graphical Abstract Keywords ABO3 perovskite oxide Surface engineering Acid treatment Surface property Surface oxygen species CO and CH4 oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Oxidation of combustible gases is extensively studied owing to its essential role in controlling environmental pollution, converting energy, and optimizing fuel utilization [1–7]. Within this scope, the oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO) and methane (CH4) is particularly significant for their relevance in mitigating toxic emissions and enhancing fuel efficiency in industrial and transportation systems [8–12]. Consequently, extensive research focuses on developing efficient catalysts to achieve the complete oxidation of CO and CH4. Platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts, including Pt, Pd, and Rh, are commonly preferred for their outstanding catalytic activity. However, their high cost and vulnerability to deactivation at elevated temperatures restrict their widespread applications [13,14]. To overcome these limitations, transition metal oxides have been proposed as promising alternatives. These compounds exhibit excellent catalytic performance while offering superior thermal stability and lower cost [15,16]. Specifically, among transition metal oxides, ABO3 perovskite oxides have garnered interest as potential substitutes for PGM catalysts. Perovskite oxides exhibit a flexible ABO3 structure, wherein alkali, alkaline earth, or rare-earth cations occupy the A site, and transition metal cations occupy the B site. This flexibility stems from the ability of these compounds to accommodate over 90 % of the elements in the periodic table at either the A or B site, allowing extensive compositional tuning [17,18]. This structural versatility of perovskite oxides, combined with their intrinsic redox properties and thermal stability, makes them highly suitable for catalytic applications, including CO and CH4 combustion. Despite these promising characteristics, however, the active sites and reaction mechanisms of perovskite oxides remain poorly understood, and their catalytic efficiency is inferior to that of PGM catalysts. To completely tap the potential of perovskite oxides as catalysts, developing strategies for improving catalytic performance based on a deeper understanding of their active sites is essential. This can be achieved by leveraging the design flexibility of perovskite oxides, particularly by modulating their surface properties through surface engineering. The surface oxygen species and B-site transition metal cations of perovskite oxides critically influence their catalytic activity in oxidation reactions. These surface oxygen species are classified into surface lattice oxygen (Olat) and surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads), with Oads formed through oxygen adsorption at surface oxygen vacancies [19,20]. During this formation process, gaseous oxygen adsorption at surface oxygen vacancies induces electron withdrawal from adjacent cations. This electron transfer leads to electron occupancy in O2-2π* orbitals, causing elongation and dissociation of the O–O bond, followed by the formation of Oads [21]. While A-site cations primarily stabilize the perovskite structure with minimal impact on catalytic activity, B-site cations play a crucial role in facilitating redox reactions and providing active sites for reactant adsorption [22–24]. During CO oxidation, Oads species play a crucial role in facilitating CO conversion and carbon dioxide (CO2) generation [25]. J. Yang et al. reported that introducing surface oxygen vacancies through Sr doping in LaCoO3 perovskites promotes Oads formation [21]. These Oads species then react with CO to produce CO2, thereby improving catalytic activity during CO oxidation. Meanwhile, CH4 oxidation proceeds via a more complex mechanism. Specifically, CH4 undergoes homolytic cleavage, resulting in the adsorption of methyl radicals on B-site cations and hydrogen radicals on Olat, initiating C–H bond activation [23,26]. Subsequent reactions between these adsorbed species and Olat produce CO2, H2O, and surface oxygen vacancies through the Marsvan Krevelen mechanism. The resulting oxygen vacancies enhance oxygen mobility, replenish Olat, and promote CH4 oxidation. Thus, Olat species, B-site cations, oxygen vacancies, and oxygen mobility are key factors governing the catalytic activity of perovskites during CH4 oxidation [27]. The distinct mechanisms underlying CO and CH4 oxidation highlight the importance of designing perovskite surfaces with active sites optimized for each reaction. Surface engineering methods for perovskite oxides are broadly categorized into two primary approaches. The first approach adjusts the stoichiometry of A- and B-site cations or introduces dopants during catalyst synthesis [20,28–30]. Meanwhile, the second approach utilizes post-treatment methods, such as acid treatment or reductive thermal treatment, to modify surface composition and properties after synthesis [31–33]. Among these approaches, acid treatment demonstrated particular effectiveness. This treatment selectively removes A-site cations due to their relatively longer and weaker A–O bonds compared to the stronger B–O bonds, thereby exposing more B-site cations on the surface [34–37]. The formation of A-site vacancies is accompanied by the generation of oxygen vacancies to maintain charge neutrality, which in turn alters the electron states of B-site cations and surface oxygen species, significantly influencing the catalytic performance of perovskite oxides. In a previous study, we demonstrated the efficacy of acid treatment in engineering surface oxygen vacancies in LaCoO3 perovskites [38]. In this scenario, acid treatment generated abundant surface oxygen vacancies while preserving the original perovskite structure, significantly enhancing catalytic performance in CO oxidation. Thus, acid treatment is an advantageous surface engineering method for tailoring the active sites of perovskite oxides, particularly surface oxygen species and B-site cations. Considering the distinct active site requirements of CO and CH4 oxidation, we hypothesized that acid treatment would enhance the catalytic activity of perovskite oxides for both reactions. In this study, LaMnO3 and LaCoO3 recognized for their superior catalytic performance in oxidizing combustible gases, were chosen as model perovskite catalysts. Acid treatment was employed to modify the surface properties of these catalysts and enhance their activity. Various characterization techniques were used to analyze the effects of acid treatment on surface properties and catalytic performance. The results confirmed that acid treatment induced distinct surface property changes in the two perovskites, leading to differing catalytic behaviors. Overall, this study offers valuable insights into the effects of acid treatment on perovskite oxides and underscores the importance of tailoring surface engineering strategies to enhance catalytic performance for specific reactants. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 LaMO3 (M = Mn, Co) perovskites LaMO3 (M = Mn, Co) catalysts were synthesized using the citrate sol–gel method. Lanthanum(Ⅲ) nitrate (La(NO3)3·6 H2O), manganese(Ⅱ) nitrate (Mn(NO3)2·4 H2O), and cobalt(Ⅱ) nitrate (Co(NO3)2·6 H2O), all sourced from SigmaAldrich were used as precursors for La, Mn, and Co, respectively. First, 1.6 g of manganese nitrate or 1.8 g of cobalt nitrate was dissolved in 50.0 mL of deionized water along with 4.8 g of citric acid. Separately, a lanthanum precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 2.7 g of lanthanum nitrate in 30.0 mL of deionized water. This solution was then added to the transition metal precursor solution while stirring continuously at 600 rpm. The mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature, and subsequently heated to 80 ℃ to facilitate solvent evaporation until a gel formed. The obtained gel was then dried for 12 h at 200 ℃, ground into a fine powder, and calcined in a muffle furnace at 800 ℃ for 5 h. The prepared LaMnO3 and LaCoO3 catalysts were designated as LMO and LCO, respectively. 2.1.2 Acid-treated perovskite catalysts We conducted acid treatment by immersing 0.4 g of the synthesized LMO and LCO catalysts in 8 mL of a 0.2 M nitric acid (HNO3) solution for 1 or 5 h. These treatment durations were selected based on our previous study [38], which demonstrated that acid treatment for 1 h and 5 h effectively modified the surface properties and enhanced the catalytic activity of perovskite catalyst. After treatment, the samples were rinsed with deionized water to remove residual acid and then dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h. These acid-treated samples were designated as LMO_ATX and LCO_ATX, where X denotes the acid treatment time. 2.2 Characterization 2.2.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The crystal structures of the catalysts were analyzed using XRD (SmartLab, Rigaku, λ = 1.54056 Å) over a 2θ range of 10°–90°. 2.2.2 Inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry (ICP–AES) We analyzed the elemental compositions of the samples using ICP–AES (OPTIMA 8300, PerkinElmer). 2.2.3 N2 adsorption–desorption analysis The specific surface areas (SBET) of the catalysts were determined using N2 adsorption–desorption at 77 K with a constant-volume adsorption analyzer (Tristar Ⅱ 3020, Micromeritics). The surface area calculations were performed based on the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. 2.2.4 Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) Catalyst morphologies were observed using FESEM (LEO SUPRA 55, Carl Zeiss) with a 10 kV electron beam. Here, samples were mounted on carbon tape and coated with Pt before imaging. 2.2.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS analysis was performed using a K-alpha spectrometer (Thermo Fisher) equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source. The O 1 s, Co 2p and Mn 2p spectra were deconvoluted using Gaussian peak fitting. Binding energies were calibrated to the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV. 2.2.6 NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) NH3-TPD was conducted using a BELCAT B instrument (Microtrac MRB). Prior to measurement, samples (0.05 g) were pretreated in a quartz tube under 5 % O2/He flow (50 mL min−1) at 800 ℃ for 1 h. After cooling to 50 ℃, NH3 adsorption was initiated by introducing a 5 % NH3/He mixture (50 mL min−1) for 1 h. To remove any physically adsorbed NH3, the sample was purged with He at 50 ℃ for 30 min. The desorbed NH3 was then monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) while recording the TPD profiles across a temperature range of 50 ℃–800 ℃. 2.2.7 O2-temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) O2-TPD analysis was performed under identical conditions to those used for NH3-TPD analysis, with the exception that a 5 % O2/He gas mixture was used for adsorption instead of NH3. The desorbed O2 was monitored by TCD during temperature-programmed desorption from 50 ℃ to 800 ℃ under He flow. 2.2.8 H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) H2-TPR was performed using the same apparatus as that used for NH3-TPD. Samples (0.05 g) were pretreated under Ar flow (50 mL min−1) at 200 ℃ for 1 h, followed by purging at 50 ℃ for 30 min. Reduction was conducted under a 5 % H2/Ar mixture (50 mL min−1) over temperatures ranging 50 ℃–800 ℃. 2.2.9 CH4-temperature-programmed surface reaction (CH4-TPSR) CH4-TPSR was performed using the BELCAT B system. Samples (0.05 g) were pretreated under 5 % O2/He flow (50 mL min−1) at 800 ℃ for 1 h, following which they were purged with He at 50 ℃ for 30 min. The reaction was conducted under 5 % CH4/He gas flow (50 mL min−1), and TPSR profiles were recorded over temperatures ranging 50 ℃–800 ℃. 2.3 Catalytic activity assessment The catalytic activities of the catalysts for CO and CH4 oxidation were evaluated in a continuous-flow quartz reactor. The reaction temperature was ramped from 50 ℃ to 600 ℃ at a rate of 2.5 ℃ min−1. The feed gas composition for CO oxidation was 2 % CO, 10 % O2, and 88 % N2, while for CH4 oxidation, it was 1 % CH4, 10 % O2, and 89 % N2. The catalytic reactions were conducted at a weight hourly space velocity of 96,000 mL gcat −1 h−1, with a total flow rate of 80 mL min−1. Reactants and products were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (ChroZen GC, Young In Chromass) equipped with a TCD. Catalytic activity was assessed by quantifying the conversion of CO and CH4, as CO2 was the sole detected product. CO and CH4 conversion was calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) CO conversion = moles o f CO consumed moles o f CO in the feed × 100 ( % ) (2) C H 4 conversion = moles of C H 4 consumed moles o f C H 4 in the feed × 100 ( % ) 2.4 Density functional theory (DFT) DFT calculations were conducted to evaluate the oxygen vacancy formation energies of the LMO and LCO catalysts. Detailed computational methods and slab model descriptions are provided in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Pristine perovskite catalysts 3.1.1 Elemental composition and crystal structure The synthesis of LMO and LCO perovskite oxides was confirmed by investigating their compositional and structural properties using ICP–AES and XRD. ICP–AES analysis revealed Mn/La and Co/La molar ratios consistent with the stoichiometric value of 1.0, confirming the incorporation of La, Mn, and Co into the perovskite structure ( Table 1). As shown in Fig. 1, the XRD patterns of the synthesized LMO and LCO catalysts matched well with the JCPDS cards for LaMnO3 (#86–1233) and LaCoO3 (#48–0123), respectively, indicating successful crystal formation with no detectable secondary phase [39,40]. These findings demonstrate that the pristine perovskite catalysts exhibit high phase purity and a stoichiometrically consistent elemental composition, ensuring their suitability for catalytic performance evaluations. 3.1.2 Catalytic performance in CO and CH4 oxidation The catalytic activities of LMO and LCO perovskites for CO and CH4 oxidation were evaluated. Fig. 2 presents the conversion rates of CO and CH4 as functions of the reaction temperature. LCO demonstrated superior activity during CO oxidation, achieving 100 % CO conversion at 250 ℃, which is lower than the temperatures required for 100 % CO conversion in LMO (300 ℃). The T50 values, defined as the temperatures at which 50 % conversion is achieved, were 206 ℃ for LCO and 247 ℃ for LMO. Meanwhile, LMO demonstrated higher activity during CH4 oxidation, achieving a T50 value of 518 ℃, while LCO exhibited only 25 % conversion at 600 ℃. These results underscore the distinct catalytic behaviors of LMO and LCO in CO and CH4 oxidation. According to previous studies on perovskite catalysts for the oxidation of combustible gases, this difference is thought to arise from variations in their surface properties, which are considered important determinants of catalytic activity [21,27]. 3.1.3 Surface oxygen species Catalytic activities of perovskite oxides are strongly influenced by their surface oxygen species. Therefore, the differences observed in the catalytic behaviors of the LMO and LCO catalysts were hypothesized to arise from variations in the properties of surface oxygen species, attributed to differences in B-site cations (Mn and Co). To investigate the origin of these contrasting catalytic behaviors, we performed XPS analysis to investigate the surface oxygen species of the catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 3, signals corresponding to three types of surface oxygen species were detected: Olat at approximately 529.0 eV, Oads at 531.3 eV, and surface-adsorbed water (Ow) at 533.2 eV [41–43]. Table 2 summarizes the relative amounts of these surface oxygen species. The data revealed that LCO exhibited a higher proportion of Oads, while LMO featured a greater proportion of Olat. This trend is further supported by DFT calculations, which show that the oxygen vacancy formation energy of LCO is lower than that of LMO, indicating that LCO more readily forms surface oxygen vacancies (Table S1). Given that low-electron-density oxygen species are more active in various catalytic reactions, their binding energy positions were also analyzed [24,44]. This analysis revealed that Oads species in LCO exhibited higher binding energy compared to those in LMO, indicating that these species possess lower electron density and higher reactivity. In contrast, Olat species in LMO exhibited higher binding energy than those in LCO, suggesting greater activity of Olat in LMO. These findings indicate that the observed activities of the both catalysts in CO and CH4 oxidation are linked to the properties of surface oxygen species. Specifically, LCO’s superior CO oxidation activity stems from its abundant and active Oads species, whereas LMO’s superior CH4 oxidation activity is linked to its rich and active Olat species. Based on the above findings, we explored surface engineering strategies to enhance the catalytic activities of LMO and LCO. Among the available surface engineering strategies, acid treatment was deemed effective for modifying the surface properties of the catalysts. Notably, acid treatment selectively etches surface La cations, resulting in the formation of surface La vacancies. To maintain charge neutrality, the perovskite structure compensates by forming oxygen vacancies, thereby enriching the surface with these vacancies and exposing more B-site cations. During CO oxidation, these enriched surface oxygen vacancies are expected to increase the proportion of Oads, thereby enhancing catalytic activity following acid treatment. Meanwhile, during CH4 oxidation, the initial activation of CH4 relies on both B-site cation and Olat species. Activated CH4 reacts with Olat through the Marsvan Krevelen mechanism, producing CO2, H2O and surface oxygen vacancies. An abundance of these oxygen vacancies increases oxygen mobility, replenishing Olat and promoting CH4 combustion. Thus, enhanced oxygen mobility, driven by enriched oxygen vacancies and increased exposure of B-site cations from acid treatment, is anticipated to improve catalytic activity during CH4 oxidation. 3.2 Acid-treated perovskite catalysts 3.2.1 Compositional and physical properties The effect of acid treatment on the compositional and physical properties of the LMO and LCO catalysts was investigated using ICP–AES, N2 adsorption–desorption analysis, FESEM, and XRD. ICP–AES analysis revealed significant compositional changes in both LMO and LCO after acid treatment ( Table 3). Specifically, the Mn/La and Co/La ratios increased following acid treatment and rose further with longer treatment times. These results indicate the selective removal of La, providing clear evidence of acid-treatment-induced surface modification. As indicated in Table 3, N2 adsorption–desorption analysis detected a slight increase in the SBET values of both catalysts following acid treatment. This indicates that acid treatment does not substantially affect the SBET values of LMO and LCO. Thus, the SBET values of the catalysts likely do not influence their catalytic performance in CO and CH4 oxidation. Morphological changes in the catalysts were examined using FESEM, as illustrated in Fig. 4. The FESEM images revealed that the surface of pristine LMO is relatively smooth, while those of its acid-treated variants (LMO_ATX) appear rough. A similar trend was observed for LCO and its acid-treated variants (LCO_ATX). HNO3 selectively etched La, inducing changes in surface composition of A- and B-site cations. These acid-treatment-induced surface modifications were confirmed to impact the morphological properties of the LMO and LCO catalysts, consistent with the findings of our previous study [38]. The XRD patterns of acid-treated LMO and LCO confirmed the preservation of LaMnO3 and LaCoO3 perovskite structure, with no additional phases or structural collapse ( Fig. 5). However, a detailed analysis of the primary diffraction peak ((110) plane) revealed a noticeable shift to lower 2θ values in both acid-treated LMO and LCO. As described by Bragg’s law ( n λ = 2 d sin θ ), this shift corresponds to increased interplanar spacing, indicating lattice expansion (Table 3) [45]. This lattice distortion is attributed to the generation of oxygen vacancies, caused by the selective La etching during acid treatment. The observed compositional and physical changes in the acid-treated catalysts confirm that acid treatment induces the formation of surface oxygen vacancies while preserving the perovskite framework. 3.2.2 Catalytic performance of the acid-treated perovskites Next, we evaluated the catalytic performance of the acid-treated LMO and LCO (LMO_AT1, LMO_AT5, LCO_AT1, and LCO_AT5) during CO and CH4 oxidation reactions, as depicted in Fig. 6. The T20 and T50 values, defined as the temperatures at which 20 % and 50 % reactant conversion were achieved, are summarized in Table 4. Acid treatment improved the catalytic activities of both LMO and LCO during CO oxidation, as evidenced by the reductions in their T20 and T50 values. For instance, T50 decreased from 247 ℃ for pristine LMO to 186 ℃ for LMO_AT1 and 190 ℃ for LMO_AT5, indicating substantial improvement. Similarly, it decreased from 206 ℃ for pristine LCO to 161 ℃ for LCO_AT1 and 158 ℃ for LCO_AT5. Notably, among all the catalysts, LCO_AT5 demonstrated the highest CO oxidation activity. However, during CH4 oxidation, the catalysts exhibited contrasting trends. Specifically, the acid-treated LCO catalysts demonstrated improved performance. T20 decreased from 583 ℃ for pristine LCO to 481 ℃ for LCO_AT1 and 460 ℃ for LCO_AT5, indicating clear improvement with extended acid treatment. In contrast, for LMO, T20 increased from 471 ℃ for the pristine catalyst to 509 ℃ for LMO_AT1 and 548 ℃ for LMO_AT5. Thus, LCO, which initially exhibited poorer catalytic performance compared to LMO, matched LMO’s performance after acid treatment, with LCO_AT5 achieving a T50 value comparable to that of LMO. The structural stability of the catalysts during CO and CH4 oxidation was subsequently assessed. XRD patterns of the catalysts collected after CO (LMO(CO_U), LMO_ATX(CO_U), LCO(CO_U), and LCO_ATX(CO_U)) and CH4 (LMO(CH4_U), LMO_ATX(CH4_U), LCO(CH4_U), and LCO_ATX(CH4_U)) oxidation were obtained (Fig. S4). All spent catalysts retained their own structural integrity after the reactions. Moreover, the long-term stability of LCO_AT5 was evaluated at reaction temperatures of 175 ℃ for CO oxidation and 575 ℃ for CH4 oxidation, each for 30 h. The results, presented in Fig. S5, indicate that LCO_AT5 achieved 100 % CO conversion and approximately 80 % CH4 conversion under the above conditions, demonstrating its superior stability. In summary, while acid treatment enhanced CO oxidation activity for both LMO and LCO, it had contrasting effects on their CH4 oxidation activity, suggesting that the CO and CH4 oxidation reactions require distinct active sites. Additionally, we inferred that acid treatment altered the surface properties of the two catalysts differently, resulting in the observed differences in their catalytic performance. Further characterizations were conducted to elucidate the reasons underlying these trends. 3.2.3 Surface chemical properties of the catalysts The surface chemical composition of the catalysts was analyzed using XPS ( Fig. 7 and Table 5). The O 1 s spectra of both catalysts revealed notable changes in the distribution and binding energy of surface oxygen species after acid treatment. For both LMO and LCO, the Oads proportion increased following acid treatment. Additionally, the binding energy of Oads shifted to higher values, indicating reduced electron density. These results suggest that acid treatment promotes the formation of more active Oads. A correlation analysis between the binding energy of Oads and T50 for CO oxidation revealed a linear relationship, underscoring the importance of active Oads in boosting CO oxidation activity (Fig. S6(a)). In addition to Oads, the binding energy of Olat also increased after acid treatment for both catalysts. However, unlike Oads, the binding energy of Olat exhibited no clear linear correlation with T20 for CH4 oxidation (Fig. S6(b)). Acid-treated LCO catalysts exhibited increases in both the binding energy of Olat and CH4 oxidation activity. In contrast, acid-treated LMO catalysts exhibited higher Olat binding energy but lower CH4 oxidation activity. These results suggest that the CH4 oxidation activity of the catalysts may depend on factors beyond the binding energy of Olat. The Mn 2p and Co 2p XPS spectra of the catalysts offer additional insights into the changes in the valence states of B-site cations following acid treatment. In the spectra of LMO, Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 peaks appeared at binding energies of approximately 655.0 eV and 642.0 eV, respectively. Peak deconvolution confirmed the coexistence of Mn3+ (653.5 and 642.1 eV) and Mn4+ (655.8 and 644.4 eV), demonstrating mixed valence states in LMO [35,46]. Acid treatment increased the Mn4+/Mn3+ ratio, indicating a shift toward higher oxidation states. Similarly, the Co 2p spectra displayed peaks at approximately 795.0 eV and 780.0 eV, corresponding to Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2, respectively. Peak deconvolution confirmed the coexistence of Co3+ (795.2 eV and 779.6 eV) and Co2+ (796.6 eV and 781.0 eV) oxidation states [47,48]. Acid treatment increased the Co2+/Co3+ ratio, indicating a shift toward lower oxidation states. Notably, the above changes in valence states are attributed to the oxygen vacancies created by the etching of surface La during acid treatment. Specifically, the removal of La triggers local electronic redistribution, altering the oxidation states of B-site cations [31,32,49,50]. For the LMO and LCO catalysts, acid treatment induced opposite trends in the Mn and Co valence states: the proportion of Mn4+ increased relative to that of Mn3+ in LMO, while the proportion of Co2+ increased relative to that of Co3+ in LCO. This difference suggests that the effects of acid treatment on B-site cations vary across perovskite catalysts. In the LCO perovskite structure, Co4+ cations are unstable owing to their high energy [51]. Consequently, LaCoO3 perovskite oxides primarily comprise Co3+ and Co2+ species. Thus, the acid treatment of LCO leads to La cation etching and oxygen vacancy formation, reducing nearby Co3+ species to Co2+. In contrast, stabilization in LMO is influenced by the JahnTeller distortion associated with Mn3+ cations (t2 g 3eg 1). This distortion, attributed to asymmetric electron distribution, unevenly alters Mn–O bond lengths, thereby stabilizing the lattice [52]. Mn4+ cations (t2 g 3) exhibit a symmetric electron distribution, and their formation is energetically favorable within the LMO perovskite framework. Conversely, Mn2+ cations (t2 g 3eg 2) exhibit an asymmetric electron distribution and are reported to preferentially occupy A-sites in ABO3 structures due to their relatively large ionic radii [53]. This preference leads to structural instability. Thus, the increase in Mn4+ proportion, rather than Mn2+ proportion, in LMO following acid treatment is attributed to the structural stabilization effects of Mn4+ and Mn3+ cations. Previous studies have reported that during the initial activation of CH4, the low electron density of Olat enhances its ability to gain electrons from hydrogen radicals, strengthening the bond between the hydrogen radical and oxygen. Meanwhile, an increase in the first ionization energy of the B-site cation hinders its ability to donate electrons to methyl radicals, thereby weakening the bond between the methyl radical and the B-site cation [54]. In LCO, acid treatment reduced the electron density of Olat, enhancing its ability to adsorb hydrogen radicals. Furthermore, CH4 activation was promoted by the enrichment of Co2+ cations, which exhibit a lower first ionization energy compared to Co3+ and form stable bonds with methyl radicals. Conversely, in LMO, although acid treatment reduced the electron density of Olat, the abundance of Mn4+ cations, which exhibit a greater first ionization energy compared to Mn3+, weakened the bond between methyl radicals and Mn cations, thereby hindering CH4 activation. In perovskite oxides, B-site cations function as Lewis acid sites, providing adsorption sites for NH3 [55]. Therefore, NH3-TPD is widely used to characterize the properties of B-site cations in perovskite oxides. To further investigate the impact of acid treatment on the LMO and LCO catalysts, NH3-TPD analysis was performed to quantify the relative abundance of B-site cations on the catalyst surfaces. NH3-TPD profiles revealed a distinct increase in the total amount of desorbed NH₃ for both LMO and LCO following acid treatment ( Fig. 8(a), (b) and Table S2). This increase suggests that surface B-site cations are more abundant on the acid-treated catalyst, indicating that acid treatment selectively removed surface La cations, thereby enriching the surface with B-site cations. The abundance of B-site cations is strongly correlated with the performance of the catalysts in CH4 oxidation. XPS analysis revealed that the acid-treated LCO catalysts exhibited an increase in the proportion of Co2+ cations, which enhance CH4 activation. In contrast, acid-treated LMO catalysts demonstrated an increase in the proportion of Mn4+ cations, which form weaker bonds with methyl radicals. Consequently, acid-treated LCO catalysts demonstrated improved CH4 oxidation activity compared to pristine LCO. However, acid-treated LMO catalysts showed decreased CH4 oxidation activity compared to pristine LMO. To further characterize the surface oxygen species, O2-TPD measurements were performed on the LMO and LCO catalysts (Fig. 8(c), (d)). The low-temperature peak observed below 200 ℃ corresponds to weakly physisorbed oxygen, while the peak in the range of 200 ℃–600 ℃ is attributed to oxygen chemically adsorbed on oxygen vacancies (Oads) [56,57]. The desorption peak areas of Oads were quantified and are summarized in Table S3. The Oads peak area of LCO was larger than that of LMO. Furthermore, the Oads peak area increased for both catalysts after acid treatment. Notably, in LCO, the increase was significant after 1 h of acid treatment and further increased with prolonged treatment time. In contrast, although the Oads peak area of LMO also increased after acid treatment, it showed minimal change with extended treatment duration. This trend is consistent with the Oads/Olat ratios obtained from XPS analysis. These O2-TPD results further confirm that acid treatment not only affects the distribution of surface oxygen species, but also leads to distinct changes in the surface oxygen characteristics of LMO and LCO catalysts. H2-TPR analysis was conducted to evaluate the reducibility of the catalysts and investigate the effects of acid treatment on oxygen mobility ( Fig. 9(a,b)). For LMO, a reduction peak at approximately 400 ℃ was observed, corresponding to the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ [58]. The position and intensity of this peak remained largely unchanged following acid treatment, indicating that the reducibility of LMO was minimally affected by the acid treatment. In contrast, the H2-TPR profiles of LCO displayed two distinct reduction peaks: one at approximately 500 ℃, corresponding to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, and another at approximately 600 ℃, corresponding to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0 [59]. The Co3+ to Co2+ reduction temperature decreased notably with prolonged acid treatment, suggesting an enhanced reducibility. This improved reducibility indicates increased oxygen mobility, which is likely due to the significant increase in surface oxygen vacancies on acid-treated LCO [60]. XPS spectra revealed an increase in the proportion of surface oxygen vacancies for both LMO and LCO catalysts after acid treatment, with LCO demonstrating a more pronounced increase. The experimental trend is corroborated by DFT calculations, which indicate that oxygen vacancy formation is energetically more favorable in LCO than in LMO (Table S1). This difference can be attributed to the higher atomic number of Co compared to Mn, which increases the number of electrons in the antibonding orbitals of the perovskite oxide, thereby weakening the bond between the B-site transition metal and oxygen [61,62]. Consequently, the greater abundance of oxygen vacancies in LCO contributed to its superior CO oxidation activity compared to LMO. Moreover, the increased oxygen vacancies facilitates the diffusion of bulk oxygen to the surface, aiding the replenishment of Olat, a critical active site for CH4 oxidation. Thus, as acid treatment progressed, the LCO_ATX catalysts, with a significantly greater proportion of surface oxygen vacancies, exhibited improved oxygen mobility. This enhancement led to progressive improvement in the CH4 oxidation activity of LCO catalysts with prolonged acid treatment. CH4-TPSR experiments were performed to assess the reactivity of the catalysts with CH4 in the absence of gaseous oxygen (Fig. 9(c,d)). During these experiments, the reaction temperature was gradually increased under a 5 % CH4/He gas flow to monitor CH4 consumption behavior. For LMO catalysts, a CH4 consumption peak appeared at 600 ℃, while for LCO catalysts, this peak appeared at temperatures above 700 ℃. Further, the CH4-TPSR profiles of the acid-treated catalysts differed. Specifically, for LMO, the intensity of the CH4 consumption peak progressively diminished with prolonged acid treatment. In contrast, for LCO, acid treatment lowered the onset temperature for CH4 consumption and increased the corresponding peak intensity. Notably, the CH4-TPSR results align closely with the catalytic activity observed during our CH₄ oxidation performance evaluations. For LCO, acid treatment promoted the formation of more active surface oxygen species and shifted the B-site cation composition to favor CH4 activation. Furthermore, the substantial formation of surface oxygen vacancies increased oxygen mobility, enhancing the reactivity of the catalyst with CH4. Collectively, these factors contributed to the improved CH4 activation and oxidation activity of acid-treated LCO catalysts. In contrast, for LMO, although acid treatment reduced the electron density of surface oxygen species, the surface cation composition shifted unfavorably for CH4 activation. Moreover, the formation of oxygen vacancies was less pronounced, leading to a minimal impact on oxygen mobility. Consequently, the reactivity of LMO with CH4 decreased after acid treatment. 3.3 Effects of acid treatment on the perovskite catalysts and their catalytic performance Our experimental findings indicate that acid treatment modified the surface properties and altered the catalytic performance of LMO and LCO perovskites. This treatment selectively removed surface La cations, generating oxygen vacancies as a compensatory mechanism to maintain charge neutrality. This removal process altered the electron density of surface oxygen species and B-site cations. In LCO, these surface modifications enhanced both CO and CH4 oxidation activities. XPS analysis revealed a decrease in the electron density of Oads, which correlated with enhanced catalytic activity in CO oxidation. Increased surface oxygen vacancies enhanced oxygen mobility, while the enrichment of Co2+ cations promoted CH4 activation. Additionally, improved oxygen mobility facilitated the regeneration of Olat, a crucial factor for CH₄ oxidation. These synergistic effects led to remarkable catalytic improvements in acid-treated LCO catalysts. In contrast, the CH4 oxidation activity of LMO declined following acid treatment, despite improvements in its CO oxidation activity. While oxygen vacancies increased and the electron density of surface oxygen species decreased, the abundance of Mn4+ cations weakened the bond between methyl radicals and the catalyst surface, thereby hindering CH4 activation. Moreover, the formation of oxygen vacancies and the enhancement of oxygen mobility were less pronounced in LMO than in LCO, resulting in negligible improvements in its catalytic cycle. These observations account for the reduced catalytic activity of acid-treated LMO in CH4 oxidation. In summary, CO and CH4 oxidation require distinct active sites. Specifically, CO oxidation requires Oads, while CH4 oxidation relies on the synergistic interaction among B-site cations, Olat, and oxygen mobility. Acid treatment effectively tunes the surface properties of perovskite oxides, yielding catalysts that are potentially effective for both CO and CH4 oxidation. However, while acid treatment successfully enhances LCO's activity for both CO and CH4 oxidation, its contrasting effects on LMO highlight the need for customized surface modifications to optimize catalytic performance across different perovskite systems. These findings offer critical insights for designing efficient perovskite-based catalysts to oxidize various combustible gases. 4 Conclusions Acid treatment was employed as a strategy to enhance the catalytic performance of LMO and LCO in CO and CH4 oxidation. Pristine LMO and LCO catalysts were successfully synthesized using a citrate sol–gel method, and their catalytic activities were systematically evaluated. The catalysts exhibited distinct catalytic behaviors: LCO demonstrated higher activity in CO oxidation, while LMO excelled in CH4 oxidation. XPS analysis revealed that LCO was enriched with low-electron-density Oads species, while LMO contained abundant low-electron-density Olat species. This difference in surface oxygen species is consistent with the DFT-calculated oxygen vacancy formation energies, which indicate that LCO has a lower formation energy than LMO, thereby facilitating the generation of Oads species. Based on these findings, we inferred the critical roles of Oads and Olat in CO and CH4 oxidation, respectively. Further, acid treatment using diluted HNO3 was conducted for 1 h and 5 h to modify the surface properties of the two catalysts. Selective etching of surface La cations during acid treatment created oxygen vacancies and altered the electronic properties of surface oxygen species and B-site cations. Catalytic activity measurements revealed that acid treatment enhanced LCO’s catalytic activity for both CO and CH4 oxidation, while it improved LMO’s catalytic activity for CO oxidation but deteriorated its CH4 oxidation performance. Characterization using XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, O2-TPD and CH4-TPSR provided insights into these catalytic behaviors. XRD, XPS and O2-TPD analyses confirmed that acid treatment increased oxygen vacancies in both catalysts. Additionally, acid treatment reduced the electron densities of Oads and Olat in both catalysts. The CO oxidation activities of both catalysts improved owing to the enrichment of active Oads species. However, acid treatment resulted in noticeable differences in the CH4 oxidation behaviors of the two catalysts. In LCO, increased oxygen mobility facilitated the replenishment of Olat, which is essential for CH4 conversion, and the enrichment of surface Co2+ cations improved catalytic performance. Conversely, in LMO, an increase in the concentration of Mn4+ cations, which destabilizes methyl radical adsorption, and limited improvements in oxygen mobility deteriorated CH4 oxidation activity. Overall, this study highlights the distinct catalytic mechanisms of LMO and LCO during CO and CH4 oxidation: specifically, CO oxidation relies on Oads species, while CH4 oxidation depends on the synergistic effects of B-site cations, Olat, and oxygen mobility. While LCO benefited from the enhanced oxygen mobility and enriched Co2+ cations after acid treatment, LMO requires alternative strategies to enhance its CH4 oxidation activity. Thus, this study provides a roadmap for optimizing perovskite catalysts for the efficient oxidation of various combustible gases through tailored surface engineering approaches. coredata.dc:description: This study examined the effects of acid treatment on LaMnO3 (LMO) and LaCoO3 (LCO) perovskites and their catalytic performance in CO and CH4 oxidation. Acid treatment selectively removed La cations, creating oxygen vacancies and altering the electronic properties of surface oxygen species and B-site cations. In LCO, it increased the Co2 + concentration while reducing the electron densities of surface oxygen species. These changes reduced T20 by 39 ℃ and 123 ℃ for CO and CH4 oxidation, respectively, after 5 h of acid treatment. However, acid-treated LMO for 5 h exhibited improved CO oxidation (T20 decreased by 49 ℃) owing to enriched surface adsorbed oxygen species but declined CH4 oxidation activity (T20 increased by 77 ℃), attributed to the increased Mn4+ concentration and minimal enhancement in oxygen mobility. This study emphasizes the importance of tailored surface engineering strategies, providing insights into the systematic design of perovskite catalysts for various oxidation reactions.
